review: ABORT LAST NIGHT - My Review of GRANDMA (3 Stars)Although writer/director Paul Weitz (ABOUT A BOY, AMERICAN PIE) will most likely never be accused of being a visionary auteur, he knows how to move and entertain an audience. GRANDMA, which could easily be dismissed as a totally unambitious, artless slice of life, still managed to hold me in its dry, acerbic spell for its brief 80 minute running time. One of my friends loathed this film, calling it completely unconvincing and poorly acted, and I could have so easily leaned in his direction were it not for my deep, blind love for Lily Tomlin. Even with her terrible films, and yes, I never drank the BIG BUSINESS Kool Aid, I've always appreciated Tomlin's delightfully bitter world view. Her killer smile, commanding voice, and take no prisoners attitude has a special place in my cold, cold heart. She's a comic genius who earned her dramatic chops with her stunning performance in the 1975 classic NASHVILLE. It's been such a long time since Tomlin has starred in a movie and even longer since she's tackled a drama, so I went to GRANDMA ready to savor every delicious minute of it. Sure, she still leans on comedic beats here, but having her front and center in every frame was enough to get me through its "small time" feel. Taking place over the course of a single day, Tomlin's Elle Reid has just broken up with her much younger short-term girlfriend (Judy Greer) when her granddaughter Sage (Julia Garner from THE AMERICANS) knocks on her door. Needing an abortion that evening and unable to shoulder the cost, Sage has come begging Elle. A broke ex-poet turned teacher, Elle takes Sage on a journey to drum up the funds, encountering people in their lives with the potential to help. It's an extremely clean, simple premise, giving Tomlin one opportunity after another to rail against anyone who gets in their way.I won't spoil what happens, but the cast of characters they meet consist of some great up-and-coming and established names, including Nat Wolff (PAPER TOWNS) as the idiot who knocks Sage up, the late Elizabeth Pena who is gets to match Tomlin's anger in an amusingly explosive scene, Colleen Camp, who proves that you can mine comedy out of a single line of dialogue, Marcia Gay Harden as Tomlin's severe daughter, Laverne Cox, who unfortunately does very little with her tattoo artist role, and best of all, Sam Elliott, as a man from Elle's past. Most of these characters merely exist to shine a light on Elle's tortured, petty, cruel and stagnant personality, which is ok, because the film, after all, is called GRANDMA, not A BUNCH OF PEOPLE. Moreover, while I would watch Judy Greer in almost anything (which means I did see JURASSIC WORLD), and I find Julia Garner to be a strong, self-possessed young actor, the main attraction is Tomlin. Depending on your stomach for her brand of comic bile, you may end up savoring every moment or end up looking for a moist towelette to wipe the somewhat sitcom-like machinations off of you. I'm, of course, with the former camp, loving that Tomlin has been freed up here to "dyke out" for the first time on film, instead of having to pretend to actually enjoying kissing John Travolta, her lookalike in the execrable MOMENT BY MOMENT. Elle's take-no-prisoners brand of feminism along with her Mother Cub protective instincts make her encounters bristle with the energy of a person who's sifted through enough crap in her life. Elle is a complicated character in that she doesn't always do or say the right things, yet Tomlin's command keeps you in the game. There's a fine line between being too Sundance-like and too populist, and GRANDMA walks the tightrope quite well between the two. Yes, it's artless, often obvious, and pretty clear from the start where the whole thing will end up, but that quiet, subtle, long final shot of Tomlin feels earned. You may not know what comes next for this unstable, unreasonable, yet wholeheartedly caring person, but you'll feel confident she can handle it by the end.

Lily Tomlin is an undisputed miracle worker. She's already been comedy royalty for decades, from her time on Laugh-In to 9 To 5, and she even has an Oscar nomination to her name for the classic Nashville. Why? Because she has a range and skills that cut deeper than laughs. But no actual Oscar wins. Perhaps this wonderful gem of a film will finally do it. This is Tomlin in a tour de force.It's not that the 75-year-old Tomlin is warming hearts as a sweet old dearie fighting off illness or senility. Writer-director Paul Weitz (About a Boy) manages to play to her strengths. Tomlin is Elle Reid, a celebrated poet with a real mouth on her, and Tomlin uses the role to take on hypocrisy head on. Her longtime partner has just died and she's just dumped a new, younger version (Judy Greer). That's when Elle's teen granddaughter Sage (Julia Garner) shows up and announces she's pregnant.The film is an absolute delight as Elle and Sage go on a no-bull search for 'a reasonably priced abortion', causing down on her luck Grandma to come across that baby daddy (a hilarious Nat Wolff), as well as Sage's mother (an excellent Marcia Gay Harden) and Karl (a terrific Sam Elliott), an old flame from Elle's past. Every encounter reveals long-buried feelings Elle can't just shrug off, and Tomlin, ever the artist, will leave you astonished and devastated.

A perfect little indie comedy. Short and sweet and showcases why Lily Tomlin is the best. It's not re-inventing anything but it has a mature and nice look at some topical subjects. I enjoyed myself thoroughly
Fantastic. It will DEFINITELY be the best movie starring a 76 year old woman you will see this year.:)

A small story with a big performance from Lily Tomlin who gives an Oscar-worthy performance as Elle, an elderly woman who recently lost her life partner and is on the rocks with her current, much younger girlfriend. Her day starts when her granddaughter comes to her for help after finding out she is pregnant. The two go on a mini road trip to collect money. At the same time, we are introduced to Elle's past as we meet an array of characters that filled her past. This is where we get to find out who Elle was as a person. This is Tomlin's show and she is sharp, witty, funny, and sentimental. Though this is seen as a comedy, the story is rather sad as it is about regrets and moving on. But, Tomlin is the main reason to see this and she will make you want a grandma like her.Grade: A-
Lily Tomlin. Abortion road trip comedy. Hilarious. Poignant. 82 minutes long. Brilliant. Watch it.
"Grandma" is a sincere little comedy that proves you are never too old to come of age.

"Grandma" is one of those short little nice independent films that touches the heart showing that life is full of change, hope and finding a new path for each. The grand old Lily Tomlin is Elle a past her prime college professor who's down in the dumps she's broke money wise and she's just broken up with her gay lady love Olivia(Judy Greer). To complicate matters one day her granddaughter Sage shows up one day needing 600 dollars and guess what it's for an abortion as Sage was knocked up by her boyfriend who hit the road! Then it's a funny and feel good road journey to obtain the 600 for an abortion and along the way it's a bonding of love and friendship as Sage's mother and Elle's daughter Judy(Marcia Gay Harden)an uptight and business like society snob provides the money for the procedure. Still thru it all each discover a journey of hope and a new beginning and Lily Tomlin's performance is shining even with her grand old age.

Lily Tomlin is voortreffelijk in haar prestatie van een oma die alles doet voor haar kleinkind en geen gelul van mensen wilt aannemen. Paul Weitz maakt hiermee zijn beste film sinds About A Boy, omdat deze eindelijk aanvoelt als een film over echte mensen en hun moeilijke relaties met elkaar.

I thought this was a very disappointing movie, with Lily Tomlin's aggressive but unfunny style, and the young girl far too accepting of everything going on around and to her to be convincing. I saw this on a plane for free and I would not pay to see it.

This film is way too eager to wrap up all its story lines as cleanly and quickly as possible and that's unfortunate because there was too much to tell and the filmmakers haven't exhausted even a small portion of possibilities created by these characters, above all by the cocky, bossy, anti-dogmatic, anti-pragmatic, no-nonsense, don't-fuck-with-me free spirit, Elle Reid. Yeah, she's a bit of an indie clich� but Lily Tomlin is on steroids here and I loved the turn the character took in the final act (if only they had the balls to go deeper in that particular story line, they could have come up with something great). So at the end of the movie, we have four characters in constant conflicts with each other and they suddenly find ways to resolve the conflicts but if you ask me how we came to that resolution, all I could come up with would be: by a twisted version of divine intervention. One of the conflicts (between Elle and her lover of a year and a half, Olivia) is your typical indie filler. It takes too much time, it contributes little to the overall narrative, but it's kinda cool and it even works somehow, mostly thanks to the two terrific, underused actresses portraying Elle and Olivia (Judy Greer always does so much with so little). And that's too bad, because the film is fun. It's affectionate and smart, but it never ever makes a bold storytelling choice. The actors are bold, yeah, once again - Lily Tomlin, you're a goddess, but the writing, the writing needs work. Actually, starting from scratch would be a good idea. End of rant.

An inter-generational movie about a quest to abort a child, grandchild and great-grandchild. Lets all bond and get closer through abortion... I wouldn't doubt it if Planned Parenthood financed most of this. You mix in some LGBT theme and of course it's catnip for the critics that are employed by left-wing media outlets. It's as bad as having Christian ministers critiquing Passion of the Christ. I'll give it one star for Lily Tomlin. Next, a story about inner city kids bonding through dog fighting.

What a movie! Lily Tomlin never leaves a scene and she is spectacular. Really enjoyed Sam Elliott's scene. That scene alone was worth the price of admission. The supporting cast, the writing, and the acting are all top notch. Comedic movies with messages don't come around often, but when they do and are done this well they are a treasure.
gotta say, Grandma never came to my local thater a.n.d. I just joined up Netflix to see it tonight, New Year's Eve, and they show no matches. What's up fans? How do I get to see this movie?

This movie stank! It's basically about a bitchy woman being bitchy to everyone she comes across, even though she is asking favors of. This was not a comedy, this was an annoying, grating portrayal of an unlikeable woman acting badly. I hated it. It was not a comedy. My friend and I did not laugh at all.
Heart. Humor. And Paul Weitz at the helm. It's made to see with that sarcastic, offbeat family member who's a black sheep in your own family.
You want to like this movie. But it falls short in too many places. It is very in-your-face at an attempt to be bold but instead it just rubs you the wrong way.

A perpetual theme of Grandma is its tolerance of progressive ideas and actions. In a scene that sets out to be more prophetic than it actually is, our titular character, played by Lily Tomlin, claims that hatred and ignorance is the way the world errs most. But hatred is what fuels Tomlin-she rips on everyone who does not fall into her mold, that of the new wave. It's a tireless effort that is boosted by the supporting cast rather than in-your-face leads. Recent films like Me and Earl and the Dying Girl do this "small landscape" genre right, while Grandma relies more on propaganda and clich�s than structure.

I really wanted to love this movie (I always want to love brave independents) but I ended up merely tolerating it. Nice to see Lily Tomlin at work in a good role. Someone point me to a feminist film that doesn't bash males and I'll be very much in your debt...
Featuring an excellent performance by Lily Tomlin, Grndma is funny and heart-warming, and one of the best films of the summer.
Lily Tomlin. Abortion road trip comedy. Hilarious. Poignant. 82 minutes long. Brilliant. Watch it.
"Grandma" is a sincere little comedy that proves you are never too old to come of age.

"Grandma" is one of those short little nice independent films that touches the heart showing that life is full of change, hope and finding a new path for each. The grand old Lily Tomlin is Elle a past her prime college professor who's down in the dumps she's broke money wise and she's just broken up with her gay lady love Olivia(Judy Greer). To complicate matters one day her granddaughter Sage shows up one day needing 600 dollars and guess what it's for an abortion as Sage was knocked up by her boyfriend who hit the road! Then it's a funny and feel good road journey to obtain the 600 for an abortion and along the way it's a bonding of love and friendship as Sage's mother and Elle's daughter Judy(Marcia Gay Harden)an uptight and business like society snob provides the money for the procedure. Still thru it all each discover a journey of hope and a new beginning and Lily Tomlin's performance is shining even with her grand old age.
An awkward movie about a awkward subject, but worth watching just for Lily Tomlin.

Lily Tomlin is voortreffelijk in haar prestatie van een oma die alles doet voor haar kleinkind en geen gelul van mensen wilt aannemen. Paul Weitz maakt hiermee zijn beste film sinds About A Boy, omdat deze eindelijk aanvoelt als een film over echte mensen en hun moeilijke relaties met elkaar.

And that's too bad, because the film is fun. It's affectionate and smart, but it never ever makes a bold storytelling choice. I wouldn't doubt it if Planned Parenthood financed most of this. You mix in some LGBT theme and of course it's catnip for the critics that are employed by left-wing media outlets. gotta say, Grandma never came to my local thater a.n.d. I just joined up Netflix to see it tonight, New Year's Eve, and they show no matches. What's up fans? How do I get to see this movie?

This movie stank! It's basically about a bitchy woman being bitchy to everyone she comes across, even though she is asking favors of. This was not a comedy, this was an annoying, grating portrayal of an unlikeable woman acting badly. I hated it. It was not a comedy. My friend and I did not laugh at all.
Heart. Humor. And Paul Weitz at the helm. It's made to see with that sarcastic, offbeat family member who's a black sheep in your own family.
You want to like this movie. But it falls short in too many places. It is very in-your-face at an attempt to be bold but instead it just rubs you the wrong way.
A nice small scale drama comedy with some eccentric characters. Whilst there's very little to dislike about the picture it struggles to engage the audience with its peculiar and at times harsh tone.

A standout turn from Tomlin but Garner and Harden are equally as good. Its an odd film from Weitz and its short. It feels like a lot of meet ups with various acquaintances. But its rewarding and interesting and parts funny and serious

In a scene that sets out to be more prophetic than it actually is, our titular character, played by Lily Tomlin, claims that hatred and ignorance is the way the world errs most. But hatred is what fuels Tomlin-she rips on everyone who does not fall into her mold, that of the new wave. It's a tireless effort that is boosted by the supporting cast rather than in-your-face leads. Recent films like Me and Earl and the Dying Girl do this "small landscape" genre right, while Grandma relies more on propaganda and clich�s than structure.

Featuring an excellent performance by Lily Tomlin, Grndma is funny and heart-warming, and one of the best films of the summer.

I don't understand the raves for this movie... Over- rated, Overacted,,Over written... Linear story... A sensitive subject handled insensitively.. And superficially... Flat with no angst, no climax. Other than that, it was great!
Very enjoyable movie, with a great cast! It's nice to see Lily Tomlin back in the lead role on a feature, and she reminds us why we love her!
Tomlin brings the character she displays on a Netflix series with Jane Fonda. I like quirky indie films. If you like them also this one is worth the price of admission

Lily Tomlin is hysterical in what is actually a pretty decent, touching movie. But honestly, for me, the movie is stolen by Sam Elliott. He's only in one scene, but it reminds you that he really is an underrated legend.

I walked out on this one - one of only a couple in my life. The premise was ridiculous and other than Sam Shepard's performance, I found the acting to be surprisingly stilted and unfortunately unbelievable.
Excellent movie. Well acted with a great storyline which is timely.
Excellent acting. A rather unconventional treatment of a delicate subject matter. The right to lifers must have hated this film. lol.

Lily Tomlin, whom I love, sleepwalks through this utterly monotonous, pretentious, self-conscious script that goes absolutely nowhere. I thought it looked bad from the beginning and considered walking out after five minutes, but I stayed and paid an awful price!!! And I saw it with my grandmother!!I have no idea why critics love it, because it was death!!!
Hermosa, c�mica, conmovedora...no se la pierdan.
Stunning. Absolutely stunning. For Lily Tomlin to stand out, surrounded by the power and talent of her costars, makes her achievement even more amazing. I will definitely see it again.
Unlikable characters in an unlikable story. Just did not work. If there are people like this I don't want to know them.

A film touching on every possible emotion. Grandma is a very modern film with aspects that, as controversial as they are, are presented in a way so that no matter your take on them, you will be able to enjoy. A great main cast with even small roles played well by accomplished actors.

Sorely disappointed given the cast and the framing of the movie in the trailer. This is much more of a drama than a comedy, with a lot of character development centered around Grandma. There seemed to be a lot of untapped potential for the actors whose characters I felt were flat so that I wasn't drawn in enough to care about what happened to them. The screen writing I felt lacked punch and the directing seemed canned, like he wanted you to know it was acting, not real.
This movie was about abortion! I had no clue... and being pro-life, I was offended. A movie that uses abortion as the catalyst to bring a family together is ROTTEN!!!

Lily Tomlin plays the titular grandmother, an expletives friendly new-agey lesbian, revisiting people in her life to get money for her granddaughter's abortion and in so doing, wrung out their backstories and the relationships they have with each other. Smartly written and simply made, eschewing anything that would make the stories too fanciful or contrived, this is a thoughtful and moving film, small in scale but big in heart. Needless to say, Tomlin alone was worth the price of admission already.
Lily Tomlin continues to show she is one of the true gems on and off screen. Her performance is so real. This small, picaresque film will leave you smiling

An outright delight of a movie. Nothing anyone might expect of such an offering but everything comes together to allow for layers and layers of wonderful character development and dialogue, plenty of gifts throughout. Just perfect.
This is a really lousy movie. The writing is bad, the acting isn't up to snuff, and Lily Tomlin - while she is generally brilliant and wonderfully funny - in this is a complete miscast.

Great character driven story though a little too overboard and feigned at times. This movie shows you don't need a whole lot to make a GREAT movie besides GREAT CHARACTERS, or even better than average characters though Hollywood tends to feed people the opposite and concentrate on random entertainment and random action at the moment
An enjoyable little film. B+

Cross between a comedy and the latest Apple wrist phone app to pose the unanswerable question: Is the vacuum they use to remove the fetus available for home use yet, and would they rather have a picture of Minnie Mouse or Taylor Swift on it?
Delicate mix of comedy and drama. Keeps you engaged.

Elle (Lily Tomlin) is a 70-something lesbian, feminist, and proud misanthrope. When we first meet her, she's in the process of breaking up with her much younger girlfriend. When the girlfriend asks if she ever loved her, Elle responds that their relationship amounts to nothing more than a footnote in her life story. Kindness is not Elle's strong suit. Shortly thereafter, Elle gets a visit from her teenage granddaughter Sage (Julia Garner), who looks like a real-life version of Goldilocks. Sage announces that she's 10-weeks pregnant and has an appointment to have an abortion that very evening, but needs to scrape up $600 to pay for it. Her timing could not be worse as Elle is currently broke, having just paid off all of her debts and cut up her credit cards into little pieces to make wind chimes. Though she's expecting a check in a few days, the next available appointment at the abortion clinic (apparently the only one in town) isn't for another week, so it's imperative that the cash be obtained in the next few hours.And this completes the convoluted premise.Though Elle isn't as nasty to Sage as she is to most people, she has no qualms about hiding her disappointment that her granddaughter turned out to be a sweet teenage girl instead of a crazy man-hating lunatic like her grandma. Though my own Gammy was fond of fashion critiques along the lines of "would it kill you to wear a little lipstick?" and "you wear that shirt so often that I'm starting to think it's your skin", Sage is chastised for having never read 50-year-old feminist manifestos. As Elle drives Sage from place to place to try to come up with the money, bits and pieces of her life story slowly emerge. Elle is loud and angry and extremely rude, often to people who've done nothing at all to provoke her wrath. Sage is mortified, as well she should be. Perhaps Elle's tantrums are meant to be funny (the movie is classified as a comedy, after all) but no one in my sparsely-attended showing was laughing. Other than impeccable dental hygiene and a slight softening towards the end, the woman has almost no redeeming qualities whatsoever.And Sage's mother Judy (Marcia Gay Harden) is no better, making a late game appearance as a stereotype of a fearsome, no-nonsense businesswoman with an obsequious gay male assistant. Rather than risking offending the pro-life crowd TOO much, the writers make sure that Sage's decision is given plenty of serious thought, with Elle advising her that if she has an abortion, she'll think about it every day FOR THE REST OF HER LIFE. Seriously? She's a teenager, she's no longer with the baby's father, she exhibits no religious proclivities, and the fetus is only 10 weeks old. What's to even think about? Though Tomlin's performance is good, she's playing such a bitter, hateful shrew that it's hard to even watch. Overall, I found the movie about as rich and satisfying as a set of plastic credit card wind chimes in a gentle breeze. Click.......click.......click.

Paul Weitz writes and directs this micro-budget dramedy about a lesbian grandmother who has to help her pregnant grand-daughter get enough money for an abortion before 5:45PM. The plot is a bit on the incredulous side, with protagonist Elle Reid having cut up her credit cards and being broke right before this crisis happens. Everyone she knows also just happens to be broke, and the preggo grand-daughter Sage doesn't have a dollar to her name as well. Lily Tomlin is solid in her acerbic and verbally abusive role, but its newcomer Julia Garner and her doe-y eyed stares which match her, as well as Sam Elliot and Marcia Gay Harden. Elliot does incredibly well, his scenes being the most emotional and powerful, dwarfing everything else that comes after. The humour is on and off throughout, sometimes dialogue is forced or feels flat. Overall its a decent little effort by all involved, but it easily could have been much better.
Very light on any surprise of any kind. It's a character study, but every character other than Lily Tomlin is very superficial. Not because of the actors.mmore because of the shallow sdript.

Lily Tomlin is wonderful in this; it's worth watching for her performance alone, and everyone else is pretty good too, except maybe the granddaughter although even she has her moments. The story's not going to appeal to everyone -- a gay grandmother, still recovering from the death of her partner, helping her granddaughter find the funds for an abortion -- but honestly this is a character piece for Tomlin. It does do that sort of cliche thing in films like this where it will cut to an unrelated scenery shot (a leaf, a flower, a tree) for atmosphere from time to time, which is a minor irritant for me as I've rarely seen the need for such shots. Still, charming, and worth checking out.
Lily Tomlin gives the best performance of her career on this funny, poignant, and powerful comedy. Grandma is a film that shouldn't be overlooked come Oscar season!
Way better than I expected. Breezy and low key, and everyone in the film comes off looking good, especially Marcia Gay Harden and Sam Elliot.

Lily Tomlin is an undisputed miracle worker. She's already been comedy royalty for decades, from her time on Laugh-In to 9 To 5, and she even has an Oscar nomination to her name for the classic Nashville. Why? Because she has a range and skills that cut deeper than laughs. But no actual Oscar wins. Perhaps this wonderful gem of a film will finally do it. This is Tomlin in a tour de force.It's not that the 75-year-old Tomlin is warming hearts as a sweet old dearie fighting off illness or senility. Writer-director Paul Weitz (About a Boy) manages to play to her strengths. Tomlin is Elle Reid, a celebrated poet with a real mouth on her, and Tomlin uses the role to take on hypocrisy head on. Her longtime partner has just died and she's just dumped a new, younger version (Judy Greer). That's when Elle's teen granddaughter Sage (Julia Garner) shows up and announces she's pregnant.The film is an absolute delight as Elle and Sage go on a no-bull search for 'a reasonably priced abortion', causing down on her luck Grandma to come across that baby daddy (a hilarious Nat Wolff), as well as Sage's mother (an excellent Marcia Gay Harden) and Karl (a terrific Sam Elliott), an old flame from Elle's past. Every encounter reveals long-buried feelings Elle can't just shrug off, and Tomlin, ever the artist, will leave you astonished and devastated.
Lily Tomlin is magnificent in this movie. I loved the story and I loved the relationships that developed in this movie. She deserves an Oscar for this role.
We went to see Grandma tonight and really enjoyed it.
Not a good script. Tomlin can't sustain a feature length film.

A full blooded performance by Tomlin anchors this character study. I really enjoyed the relationships between three generations of women in the same family, each woman at different stages of finding their strengths.
Brilliant and hateful film about some not very nice people doing some not very nice things. Wonderful performance by Tomlin
Great acting. Well worth watching.
Lily Tomlin hits a home run in this funny and acerbic comedy written and directed by Paul Weitz. Highly recommended!
If you're pro-life and against gay marriage, don't go. Otherwise, do go and have a good time with the dialog and the cast.

Lily Tomlin shines in one of her best roles. The film throws out a few one-liners like a sharp and twisted sitcom, whcih doesn't always work. I love how the film manages to be bold and is brave enough to make some very controversial decisions and stick with it. It doesn't give in to crowd-pleasing pressure for a conclusion all wrappped up in a night little bow.
An unexpectedly layered story featuring a fiery performance by Tomlin.
horrible, didn't care about any of the characters. pro abortion shoved down the audience's throat with stereotypes.

Do you want to know what's wrong with the world? What? Yeah, you're right, we don't have all day, and my reviews are long enough anyway. Alright, I'll narrow it down to two things: lack of responsibility and lack of respect. When people live as if their actions have no consequences (or they shouldn't be subject to any consequences arising from their choices), they show a lack of responsibility. When people don't treat others as they would want to be treated, they show a lack of respect. If you stop to think about it, I believe you'll agree that the world would be a much better place if we all were even a little more responsible in our daily lives and a little more respectful in our interactions with other people. Oh, and it's also a big problem when people make a movie in which so few of the characters are likeable. Okay, I guess that makes three things, but they're all relevant when discussing the film "Grandma" (R, 1:19).The great Lily Tomlin takes on her first lead role in a feature film since 1988 (when she starred with Bette Midler in the underrated comedy farce "Big Business"). Tomlin plays the title character in this comedy-drama about an uninhibited, but tough lesbian poet named Elle Reid and her relationship with her 18-year-old granddaughter, Sage (Julia Garner). Elle is still mourning the death of Violet, her life-partner of 38 years. That situation obviously has her emotionally edgy, but it's pretty obvious that she's always been a real pill. Sage stops by her grandma Elle's house in the morning, shortly after Elle cruelly breaks up with her much younger lover of two months (Judy Greer). Elle, in her own words, is "just being maudlin" as she goes through a box of pictures and memorabilia from her lifetime with "Vi". Sage says she needs money. She's pregnant and needs $630 to pay for an abortion she scheduled for late that day.Elle has very little cash on hand and has cut up her credit cards, so she peels the cover off of Vi's old car and takes Sage on a sort of local road trip to visit people who give them various sums of money toward their goal. They visit Sage's rude, self-centered boyfriend, Cam (Nat Wolff), Elle and Vi's old friend, Deathy (Laverne Cox) in her tattoo parlor, Elle's scowling friend, Carla (Elizabeth Pe�a), Elle's grudge-harboring old flame, Karl (Sam Elliott), and Sage's unsympathetic businesswoman mother, Judy (Marcia Gay Harden). As the day progresses, instead of an open and frank discussion about Sage's choices and the direction of her life, or even some family bonding, we see Elle being very rude to a series of one-dimensional characters that Elle clearly regards as on the wrong side of the tracks, politically-speaking."Grandma" is full of outstanding acting, but lacking in likeable characters, moral direction... and fun. Garner is well-cast and gives a nicely lived-in performance, while Elliott makes great use of his limited screen time to give an emotionally-layered performance. Tomlin is as great as ever. I just wish it were in service to a better movie. Although this film is mercifully short, it's basically a long commercial for abortion. Earlier in this review, I generously referred to this movie as a comedy-drama, but two out of three websites I checked label the film simply as a comedy. An abortion comedy?? Regardless of my personal feelings on the issue, I find the idea of a comedy about abortion to be offensive. Whether you're pro-choice, pro-life or don't care much either way, I'd like to think we could all agree that this complicated issue would have been better served by at least some discussion of Sage's options and the probable results of different courses of action. Surely nothing is to be gained by portraying the few religious and/or conservative characters in the story simply as close-minded, abusive snobs."But you're missing the point," someone reading this review is thinking. "This is a comedy about an unconventional grandmother's relationship with her granddaughter. Well, I would say in response, I can think of a hundred different ways to make a movie like that without exploiting a very serious, divisive and personal issue for comedic purposes. And even if I ignored the issue which drives this story, where's the comedy? Is it in Elle's terrible treatment of both friends and strangers? Is it in Sage's clueless lack of personal responsibility? Is it in the animosity between Elle and her daughter Judy? If that's your idea of humor, go ahead and enjoy this film. I'm not criticizing your taste in movies, but I'm not laughing either. Oh, and the movie's boring too. The director must have known that. He placed title cards between each "chapter" of this story, as if to reassure us that the plot was progressing and driving towards some point.If there's any positive message here, it's about not burning bridges in your dealings with others, but even that lesson is overshadowed by selfish and unkind characters who rarely show remorse for their actions or treat anyone with respect, being especially rude to anyone different from themselves. I don't know about you, but I had grandmas who were outspoken but loving and who taught me about personal responsibility and respect. I miss my grandmas. I wish I had missed the movie "Grandma" too. "D"

Why are the words, "for an abortion" not added in the Movie Info after the words "needing $600?" My guess is to not dissuade people from attending. They duped me, don't let them dupe you. Very flippant attitude towards a life changing procedure.

Terrific movie. I was reminded so much of women I grew up with who paid a big price for being "new women." And for once, a man who loses his child to abortion is given his due. I mean the character played brilliantly by Sam O'Neill. Tomlin is perfect, as are the whole cast. There isn't a trace of phony melodramatics, just a wonderful set of character studies.
meh! angry lily ....pffft! sarcasam and jokes are predictable. All of it is predictable. A perfect movie for the suburban progressive.

Sure not the movie I expected. The over reliance on potty language is awful.Do not know grandmothers that speak with to their grandchildren in this way. Just not comfortable hearing these words at every turn in the story. Gives edgyfeeling to story. Not so worthy film at all. B. Whelton

Grandma is a surpringly touching film about the vulnerabilities of three generations of women, a variety of relationships, and the pain people cause each other that keys in on the capacity for self-realization and healing given honest communication. The plot is tightly written, the casting superb, the acting by Lily Tomlin exceptional, and the directing sensitive and consistent. It ranks with some of the best films of the human story in the last several years, not because it is flashy or deep, but because it is credible, honest, and plainly stated for all of the characters.
WE WALKED OUT AFTER 20 MINUTES.AND RAN TO SEE A WALK IN THE WOODS which did not have a theme about an old lesbian played by Lily and her granddaughter wanting money for an abortion.
Love Lily Tomlin & can't wait to see this! (How did it not make it into the film festival?)
Why doesn't this area bring in EXCELLENT films?
Very offensive language, uninteresting plot and, legitimizes killing an unwanted child, as a disposable inconvenience.
Charming. Lily Tomlin is great, but Sam Elliot as Karl kills it. What an amazing scene.

I so wanted to like this for Lily but I hated it. I kept waiting for it to redeem itself & make it worth sitting thru but I felt dirty & depressed & very unhappy with her for taking such a role in such a rotten tomato movie. I have no idea how people are rating this so high. My friend felt exactly like I did. I liked her car. I laughed about twice. I felt ashamed of the language used in front of that poor granddaughter who was subjected to both women. I think it set back right to choose a million miles with disgusting remarks. I just really hated this movie. Awful. Sorry Lily - don't know what anyone was thinking or trying to say in this monster.
Walked out after ten minutes and I want those ten minutes back. Life is too short to spend with characters that you don't believe for a minute and can't stand all the time.
Really, really good performances--and any chance to see Lily Tomlin at work you should jump on. Also featuring the greatly grizzled Sam Elliott.
This movie was not what I expected. I loved every moment of it!

Why? If Rotten Tomato's could just be honest! This movie is poorly acted at best. But because it hits all the right politically correct buttons Tomato's is compelled to give it a high rating. Please gain some real courage and rate accordingly. Quit being a puppet for bad movers with a certain political leaning. Just sayn!
A very good movie. I would have rated this 3 stars, but Lily Tomlin's performance was spectacular, making her a shoe-in for an Oscar nomination.

Grandma is the kind of movie that makes cinema great. Probably made for $10, this is the sort of film that reminds people that movies can be great without special effects, mega-stars and huge promotional budgets. This is a movie about normal people dealing with normal problems in pretty ordinary ways. However it's perfectly written, it's very funny and quite touching at times. Of course, and as you might expect, this movie will never hit the multiplex so it will be only be seen by old people in art house theaters. If you like movies this is a total winner and certainly worth the time and price of admission.
Horrible movie...walked out half way thru!

such high-level acting from both Lily Tomlin and Julia Garneranother example of such a dysfunctional family when it comes to help and understanding of one anotherSage is pregnant and not wanting to face her cruel bully of a mother goes to her grandmother for guidance in order to have an abortiongrandmother Elle just got out of a bad breakup and she goes from flame to flame not only to bond with Sage but to clear her own conscienceit's a very short piece of work and the cast is big which is a shame because not all of them are used that much but this 'Grandma' is the one to look up tonext to Sam Elliot, Nat Wolff, Judy Greer, and John Cho, Tomlin and Garner are the real appeal as grandmother and granddaughter Elle has been through hell and the rest of her family suffered because of it particularly her daughter played by the successful, workaholic Marcia Gay Harden who always patronizes Sagestill this family comes to grips with how much they've been hurting and know they still have each other and that's the real valuethis movie is funny, heavy, raw, and truthful

Bravery can be making the most fearful thing seem like as if it could not have occurred in any other way. Grandma renews my hope in the independent films like I knew in the 90s. Lily Tomlin plays the titular character without being caricature. This one is not for everybody, but it should be. We have lesbianism, feminism, single motherhood, and abortion as topics on tap. The one day in the life road-trip without much road is deep and certain to make the conservative head spin. To my liberal friends, go see this without hesitation. Tomlin should get some best actress nominations for this one.
Lily Tomlin was perfect for this role as the R-rated Grandma
Just saw this little gem. Lily Tomlin is wonderful! What a perfect vehicle for her. Her artistry ages like a fine wine. Go see the film - you'll be glad you did.

A perfect little indie comedy. Short and sweet and showcases why Lily Tomlin is the best. It's not re-inventing anything but it has a mature and nice look at some topical subjects. I enjoyed myself thoroughly
Lily is wonderful....Oscar winning performance!!!

I love Lily Tomlin and her acting was spot on. But I expected this to be funny and it was one cliche after the next. The acting was very over the top with everything exaggerated to such a degree it was hard to connect with any scene.
The plot isn't much but Tomlin's performance makes it all worthwhile.

Talk about a waste of good talent and a huge disappointment! DO writers in Hollywood think that all aging feminists are nothing but angry nasty old women? LIly Tomlin's character is just plain unlikeable...similar to BIll Murray's character in St Voncent...just plain nasty. ALl of the trailers lesad you to think that it's a comedy...well, if she weren't so vitriolic and mean there may have been humor....but there just wasn't. And I found NO chemistry between grandma and granddaughter. So throw in the fact that many of you will dislike the preaching about abortion and lesbianism and the older woman/younger woman relationship and you've simply got a hot mess. And that is not easy to accomplish with such a stellar cast.
Grandma/I still can't believe a movie was made about a granddaughter's quest to get $650 to have an abortion and she goes to her lesbian grandmother for help. What a great movie.
I was so very disappointed. It was too dark and not funny.

A terrific movie and a joy to watch with the absolute best performance of the year from a leading actress from Lily Tomlin. She is dynamite in this movie with her sharp comedic skills and fantastic timing but still balancing a lot of great dramatic work and compassion for her character who isn't the most likable person in the world. Tomlin really deserves some awards love for this performance I just can't imagine many being better than her this year. Julia Garner is great as well as Tomlin's granddaughter and plays off Tomlin really well. I can't wait to see what else she has in store in her career. Marcia Gay Harden, Judy Greer, and Sam Elliot have limited roles as this is a road trip movie jumping from one house to another trying to find some cash for Tomlin and Davis' characters. All three are incredible in their limited screen time especially Sam Elliot who is on a roll this year with this and I'll See You in My Dreams earlier this year, showing two very different sides to him. The screenplay is fantastic and this is definitely one of Paul Weitz strongest films right up there with About a Boy. I think my only complaint with this movie was it was a little too short and sweet. I wanted a little more out of these characters especially some more backstory to Tomlin and Harden's past relationship woes as well as Tomlin and Greer's struggles. But overall, it is a blast to watch and a tour de force performance from Tomlin that can not be missed.
I strongly encourage all my middle-aged female friends to see this movie. And if you need any more enticement, it has Sam Elliott.

In Grandma, Elle (the grandma) tries to borrow money from people she knows for her granddaughter to pay for an abortion scheduled for later that day. The film acts as a road movie as Elle encounters people from her past and the journey becomes more important than the destination. As Elle, Lily Tomlin is funny in her direct and confrontational nature, where she won't take shit from anyone, but the character is much deeper, holding that part of her close to herself and trying to teach Sage, her granddaughter, the same. There's more compassion and purpose in her attitude than one might expect. Her layered performance gives us a sense of her values and her flaws. It's a great performance surrounded by great supporting performances. In Sam Elliot's brief time on screen he conveys a lifetime of hurt from his past with Elle that resonated through the film's entirety. Marcia Gay Harden's performance has that same great effect as she appears late in the film, filling in the missing generational gap between Elle and Sage. She's a tough and obsessively organized woman with a broken relationship between her mother and daughter. Harden communicates this with ease, her life a desperate attempt to maintain an illusion of control. Judy Greer succeeds in showing the experiential gap between her and Elle, and Julia Garner is careful and effective in revealing her Sage's insecurities. Paul Weitz gives each character a unique face and devotes lots of attention to each's personal issues. The dialogue ranges from witty to poignant, and the humor is very well balanced. Weitz wisely chooses not to intervene much with the simple, handheld camerawork, letting his characters speak for themselves.This movie just might fill your heart when Sage and Elle give each other a hug at the end of their long day. We see that Elle is trying to teach her granddaughter self-acceptance in a world where it's too easy to beat yourself up, because life is too short to apologize for who you are. Elle learns something about herself as well, that wanting the best for yourself doesn't mean you can't want the best for others. It's a small film with a big heart that feels true to life, and a hidden gem underneath this year's bigger ticket movies. One of the year's best, in fact.
A small movie with lots of heart and unspoken emotions. A wonderful, award worthy, performance by Lily Tomlinson.
Fantastic. It will DEFINITELY be the best movie starring a 76 year old woman you will see this year.:)

Excellent performance by veteran Lily Tomlin, who proves that older, seasoned actresses, can indeed carry a film. A one note screenplay that manages to succeed due to good supporting performances and Tomlin's charisma.
Another stupid "let's try to make homosexuality not a freakshow" movie. I watched it, but it ended up just being another ignorant lefty movie.

This movie at first glance as you watch the trailers lead you to think it is a sitcom with a bit of heart. Yet when you open to the first scene, you see an older woman (Lily Tomlin) send her lover away. It is a fact of life that there are fights and love dissipates. It is then you realize that maybe this might have more substance. This is a road picture with understated heart; most family looks on and stoically keep their feelings in check when a crisis occurs. Here Lily Tomlin plays a grandmother who fights to understand loves ebb and flow as she also tackles the fact that she has aged. Julia Gardner is not bad as the grand daughter who wishes to get an abortion, yet does not want to tell mom. Their desire to maintain dignity through their faults. Lily Tomlin is amazing and always has delivered honest work. The script gets stronger and eventually delivers the solid landing that completes the journey. Sam Elliot has a wonderful scene as the older woman's ex husband. Actually this is the best written scene in the whole movie. So I recommend this picture and hope that Ms. Tomlin continues to explore new horizons.

Did I want to see the new movie "Grandma" because I'm a grandparent myself? Did I want to see the new movie "Grandma" as sort of thank you to Lily Tomlin for her long career? Or did I want to see "Grandma" because it was less than 90 minutes long. Well definitely I'll say a little bit of each but any directors of films less than an hour and a half should get a bonus. Let's talk about Lily "Miss Piss and Vinegar" Tomlin. For me, my strongest memories of her long career was her characters on "Rowan and Martin'sLaugh In the the very early 70's. She and others burst onto the scene from that hugely successful comedy show?she was a comedic beast! My next recollection of her was with Dolly Parton and Jane Fonda in the movie "9-5" which was hugely popular comedy. I'm sure she has done many other roles but they just don't come to me. I doubt if she was ever up for any post season awards and one could say her career was unremarkable. Yet, she no doubt had a long career in her chosen field (over 40 years) and not many folks can say that. Lets also be candid, Hollywood is not open to roles for women that are not "knock outs" or older unless you are an uber box office draw. It was a magical experience for me to see her have a lead role and kill it!! (Like Blythe Danner in "I'll See You In My Dreams).The moment the movie began and her face appeared on the screen with her sarcastic way of speaking, I just started smiling. Simply I knew would really like her character and this movie. The previews were pretty clear that it's a story about her sort of estranged granddaughter who becomes pregnant and is need in need of money to get an abortion. She turns to her quirky grandmother that she's clearly been disconnected with yet trusts over her CEO, overbearing Mom (Academy Award winner Marcia Gay Harden).So it is all about the journey to find the necessary $600 fee as Tomlin (Elle) reveals her life, friends, partners to her granddaughter (mostly for the 1st time, the Sage (played very well baby Julia Garner) has a 5pm abortion appt. and to her, her back is against the wall. Elle, stops her life to help family and slowly reveals stages of her life as she keeps tracking down "friends" over the years to try to get some $."Grandma" very clearly showcases the non-traditional roles and paths of both Grandparents and our youth today?yup, we are not in Mayberry anymore.Made me reflect on how predictable, calm, generally drama-free my life was growing up along with the text book roles my grandparents played in my life as periodic folks in my life. Things were so much cleaner and uncomplicated.Follows Elle & Sage 1 day tale along with the introduction late in the film of ogre Mom and CEO Harden was both a comedy and a drama. As a total package, this film worked VERY WELL and was thrilled to see it. This movie is laced with foul language combined with lots of complicated relationships of family, friends and lovers. So down to earth, so believable, so warm and real.I love that all the lead characters in this movie are female. I love soft,background soundtrack simply supports the mood of the various themes without interfering in any way. The bad language in this film emanates from every single character and pounds home the angst in each characters lives. When used comedically worked, when used to reinforce anger/passion (generally the case), even more effective.SIDE NOTEHow lucky are we to have this BOW TIE theater in Red Bank. Seriously this movie "Grandma" and their other film "Learning To Drive" (which I reviewed last week) are both magnificent, simple films. Probably neither will gain much in the way of post season nominations nor awards, but boy are they both captivating and immensely enjoyable. Thank you Bow Tie!

Lily Tomlin is the reason to see this film and that's that. The story is funny, easy to follow, and realistic, but Tomlin's performance as an imperfect, gay, cartoonishly outlandish grandma is Oscar worthy. Or at least Golden Globe worthy.

Lily Tomlin ramps it up in a great role tailored to her talents, with able assist from the fascinating supporting cast. (I will watch Judy Greer read the phone book). That Tomlin's character starts out as mean & bitchy, and can't even scrape $600 together annoyed me to no end. But the movie really has a heart.

In Grandma, Lily Tomlin is a full-on, no holdbacks woman of a certain age who shows us what it looks like to be fully human. Everything is there in her face: grief, joy, love behind a veneer of 'I-stopped-giving-a-f**k-before you were born' even she knows is not entirely true. Julia Garner her granddaughter, Sage, is, even pregnant, the teenager you wish you had - smart and simultaneously knowing/unknowing. Marsha Gay Harden is the chili in the stew.
i thought that the coming attractions would be the best part of the movie. i was wrong. The entire movie was fantastic. Lily Tomlin should be nominate for an academy award

Tender, funny, and heartwarming, Grandma is, without a doubt, one of my favorite films of the year. Kudos to Paul Weiz for his compassionate direction and sharp script, and Lily Tomlin for her excellent portrayal of a feisty yet sensitive lesbian poet. Solid performances all around, but this film belongs to Tomlin. She is great and so is the movie. I absolutely loved it!
Go ahead, make fun of me for seeing a movie called 'Grandma,' and liking it. See if I give a shit.
This was a fairly standard indie dramedy, but it's the lead performance of Lily Tomlin that really carries it. Supporting work from Sam Elliot is nearly as strong.

+"Grandma" is a movie for every woman, grandmother, mother, daughter, any man who has been involved with the aforementioned, and definitely any fan of Lily Tomlin. She has been a force of nature from her early days in "Laugh-In" from 1970-1973 to winning a Grammy for her comedy album in 1972 to an Oscar nomination for her film debut in 1974 in "Nashville" and winning a Tony Award in 1985 for the brilliant one woman show her partner of 42 years, Jane Wagner, wrote for her "The Search For Signs Of Intelligent Life In The Universe" up to and including a 2015 Emmy nomination for outstanding lead actress in a TV comedy for "Grace and Frankie". If there is any justice in the movie business Tomlin should have an Oscar nomination for her role in "Grandma".Though her role of Elle is a tour de force for Lily Tomlin she has a strong supporting cast especially Sam Elliot in a scene that is the highlight of the film. Judy Greer, her girlfriend of 4 months, "Just a footnote", Elle tells her breaking up with her, Julia Garner as Sage , Elle's granddaughter, Marcia Gay Harden as Elle's daughter, and Sage's boyfriend, Nat Wolff, who is responsible for Sage's pregnancy which puts the story into motion. Laverne Cox as a tattoo artist friend of Elle's, Elizabeth Pena as the owner of a small book store not to forget John Cho as the owner of a coffee shop all have what are basically cameos but each impresses as being chosen for their scenes by the director and screenwriter, Paul Weitz, who wanted the best from each actor and got it.Is Lily Tomlin Elle or is Elle Lily Tomlin? From the public persona of the entertainer we all know, it is hard to decipher if they are separate or combined into one. We see Tomlin's highly skilled comic talents and in her scene with Sam Elliot plus an earlier scene where she grieves for her lover of 38 years, who died a year and a half before the movie starts, we feel the emotional range she can and does show as an actress or is it Lily Tomlin, the woman we think we know? "Grandma" is a short film, about 80 minutes including the end credits, that shows Lily Tomlin as an actress who can turn on a dime going from sarcasm to laugh out loud jokes to putting a tear in our eye with, seemingly, little effort. It touches on pregnancy, abortion, independent women, loneliness, growing/being old and what that entails, fleeting fame, how we can hurt people unknowingly, how we hurt each other mostly in short but effective scenes. One scene alone with Elle taking a shower, brushing her teeth, is more than worth the price of admission.
I saw "Grandma" on Sunday, September 6th at the AMC Rolling Hills 20. Lilly Tomlin looks great for someone her age (80+?). A cute movie.

A small story with a big performance from Lily Tomlin who gives an Oscar-worthy performance as Elle, an elderly woman who recently lost her life partner and is on the rocks with her current, much younger girlfriend. Her day starts when her granddaughter comes to her for help after finding out she is pregnant. The two go on a mini road trip to collect money. At the same time, we are introduced to Elle's past as we meet an array of characters that filled her past. This is where we get to find out who Elle was as a person. This is Tomlin's show and she is sharp, witty, funny, and sentimental. Though this is seen as a comedy, the story is rather sad as it is about regrets and moving on. But, Tomlin is the main reason to see this and she will make you want a grandma like her.Grade: A-

I didn't love this film as much as I thought I would, but still found it to be an entertaining one. The main reason to see this film is the performance of Lily Tomin, who just holds the whole movie together with some funny one liners and some some dramatic moments. The film also holds a powerful supporting cast particularly Sam Elliot and Judy Greer. The film has lots of laughs but also intense moments. The writing is extremely well done for such a simple story. I wouldn't put this film in my list of best films of 2016, but would overall say it's a terrific film. My grade=88%(B+).

ABORT LAST NIGHT - My Review of GRANDMA (3 Stars)Although writer/director Paul Weitz (ABOUT A BOY, AMERICAN PIE) will most likely never be accused of being a visionary auteur, he knows how to move and entertain an audience. GRANDMA, which could easily be dismissed as a totally unambitious, artless slice of life, still managed to hold me in its dry, acerbic spell for its brief 80 minute running time. One of my friends loathed this film, calling it completely unconvincing and poorly acted, and I could have so easily leaned in his direction were it not for my deep, blind love for Lily Tomlin. Even with her terrible films, and yes, I never drank the BIG BUSINESS Kool Aid, I've always appreciated Tomlin's delightfully bitter world view. Her killer smile, commanding voice, and take no prisoners attitude has a special place in my cold, cold heart. She's a comic genius who earned her dramatic chops with her stunning performance in the 1975 classic NASHVILLE. It's been such a long time since Tomlin has starred in a movie and even longer since she's tackled a drama, so I went to GRANDMA ready to savor every delicious minute of it. Sure, she still leans on comedic beats here, but having her front and center in every frame was enough to get me through its "small time" feel. Taking place over the course of a single day, Tomlin's Elle Reid has just broken up with her much younger short-term girlfriend (Judy Greer) when her granddaughter Sage (Julia Garner from THE AMERICANS) knocks on her door. Needing an abortion that evening and unable to shoulder the cost, Sage has come begging Elle. A broke ex-poet turned teacher, Elle takes Sage on a journey to drum up the funds, encountering people in their lives with the potential to help. It's an extremely clean, simple premise, giving Tomlin one opportunity after another to rail against anyone who gets in their way.I won't spoil what happens, but the cast of characters they meet consist of some great up-and-coming and established names, including Nat Wolff (PAPER TOWNS) as the idiot who knocks Sage up, the late Elizabeth Pena who is gets to match Tomlin's anger in an amusingly explosive scene, Colleen Camp, who proves that you can mine comedy out of a single line of dialogue, Marcia Gay Harden as Tomlin's severe daughter, Laverne Cox, who unfortunately does very little with her tattoo artist role, and best of all, Sam Elliott, as a man from Elle's past. Most of these characters merely exist to shine a light on Elle's tortured, petty, cruel and stagnant personality, which is ok, because the film, after all, is called GRANDMA, not A BUNCH OF PEOPLE. Moreover, while I would watch Judy Greer in almost anything (which means I did see JURASSIC WORLD), and I find Julia Garner to be a strong, self-possessed young actor, the main attraction is Tomlin. Depending on your stomach for her brand of comic bile, you may end up savoring every moment or end up looking for a moist towelette to wipe the somewhat sitcom-like machinations off of you. I'm, of course, with the former camp, loving that Tomlin has been freed up here to "dyke out" for the first time on film, instead of having to pretend to actually enjoying kissing John Travolta, her lookalike in the execrable MOMENT BY MOMENT. Elle's take-no-prisoners brand of feminism along with her Mother Cub protective instincts make her encounters bristle with the energy of a person who's sifted through enough crap in her life. Elle is a complicated character in that she doesn't always do or say the right things, yet Tomlin's command keeps you in the game. There's a fine line between being too Sundance-like and too populist, and GRANDMA walks the tightrope quite well between the two. Yes, it's artless, often obvious, and pretty clear from the start where the whole thing will end up, but that quiet, subtle, long final shot of Tomlin feels earned. You may not know what comes next for this unstable, unreasonable, yet wholeheartedly caring person, but you'll feel confident she can handle it by the end.
The trailer had me failing asleep within 10 seconds but the movie was quite the opposite. Very funny, fast-moving and upbeat. One of the year's best.

How I wanted to like this movie (despite its lackluster trailer). I love Lily Tomlin (most recently seen on Netflix's�"Grace and Frankie"). Not long ago, she appeared on Public Radio International's�Studio 360�to discuss her long career (born in 1939, she made her initial mark on�"Rowan & Martin's Laugh-In"�in 1970), and I was reminded of all of the quirky humor she brings to most of her performances. Unfortunately,�Grandma - though by no means terrible - does not allow much room for her to perform, at all. I blame director Paul Weitz ("About a Boy"), since most of the actors give�lazy turns, with one notable exception: Sam Elliott ("I'll See You in My Dreams"). And when he's on screen, Tomlin ups her game, as well.Grandma tells the story of young high-school student Sage - played by Julia Garner ("The Perks of Being a Wallflower"), not up to the task - who shows up on her grandmother's doorstep on the day when Grandma (Tomlin) has just broken up with her much younger girlfriend,�Olivia - played by Judy Greer ("Archer"), who is always good, no matter what. Grandma - otherwise known as Elle - is a once-well-known poet who has just paid off all medical debts from her longtime - now deceased - partner's illness. As a consequence, she has no money, and Sage�needs over $600 for an abortion. She won't go to her mother, Judy - played, eventually, by a very strident Marcia Gay Harden ("Pollock") - since Mom is everything Grandma is not: uptight, moralistic and structured. It's too bad, though, because Mom also has money.So off Sage and Elle go, in search of friends-of-Grandma to shake down for long-ago debts owed, stopping off at the boyfriend's house first, where said lunkhead threatens the old lady and gets his butt kicked for his pains. In scene after scene, we find�occasionally witty bits of sketch comedy and drama that are just as often weighed down by pedestrian direction. There is very little life on screen. It's as if Weitz were content to have scored Tomlin as his star, only to then forget that a director must guide the actors. So it comes as a sudden surprise when, in a last-ditch effort, Elle drags Sage to an old (male) flame of her own, and we meet Karl (Elliott), who bears a huge grudge towards Elle for how she left him and then wrote about him in a poem. In their scene together, we see what might have been. We feel their history, and actual emotions flow between two human beings. It's a wonder.The rest of the film - divided into six parts, each labelled as if in a poem by Elle (1. endings, 2. ink, 3. apes, etc.) - has its few moments of spark, but mostly it fizzles. When Elle and Judy reach their reconciliation - of sorts - at the end, it has long been expected, and so fails to pack an emotional punch. I wish there were more to recommend here, but at least�there's�"Grace and Frankie" available for binge-watching at home. That's not exactly an amazing series, itself, but Tomlin is much better in it than she is here.
A very loosely woven script. Lily Tomlin plays a crass, no class Lesbian grandmother. Just not any characters I relished spending time with.

I must write another brilliant screenplay for Lily Tomlin. I want to keep seeing Lily full screen and exquisitely and perfectly genius. Thank you Paul Weitz! Going to see it again tomorrow. That last scene! LILSTER!!

"Hip" lesbian Grandma takes granddaughter on a fun quest to secure $600 for the granddaughters abortion. This has to be the worst premise for a "comedy" ever. Writer/director Paul Weitz goes on my Adam Sandler List of those for whom I will never again waste money on a movie ticket.

Sometimes it feels like Lily Tomlin is always playing the same character (this one is not too different from her Netflix series character from Grace and Frankie)--but the story is well told, and unfolds in a nice, independent-film sort of way. Great supporting roles played by Marcia Gay Harden and Sam Elliot. This abortion film feels like it will always be relevant--the theme of terminating a pregnancy and how it effects the family will always be important.
A fun movie - a real showcase for Lily Tomlin - well worth your time!

This was a great story line, it really had nothing to do with the abortion, but the relationship between the grandmother, her daughter and granddaughter. In a humorous way, it shows us the painful side of how not communicating can ruin relationships. Sam Elliott gave a great performance, Having just lost a grandmother myself and being able to relate to this relationship, I found this movie to be a relief for the realistic issues that do happen and can't be shoved under the rug by society.

You know the scene in the movies where a rear view mirror in a taxi shows the eyes of the protagonist, and there's an exchange between them and the cabbie? Four times it's happened to me when the driver says, you remind me of... twice and one of those recently, suggesting Shirley MacLaine and twice I was told Lily Tomlin. Yesterday, the eyes the cabbie saw were Lily Tomlin's in the movie Grandma.No, there wasn't a remark that she reminded him of me, the shot moved to her remembering a love that made her laugh, and took her to a place where transformation was an option.Ok, I stood and line yesterday for that movie, telling my friend three times, not to tell me more about a movie, so I won't use up one more word about the plot line. I just want to say that the line waiting for the movie with us, was all wrong, comprised of people who looked like us... over 60 with hip clothes, good haircuts and as my favorite, May Sarton line, "grandmother (and father) faces"... Botox and surgery included. With a title like Grandma and starring a septuagenarian, its easy to figure that the demographic attracted will be the star's cohort, but it's an intergenerational story about love and forgiveness and making mistakes and fixing them or not in high school, in mid sophisticated career or late career later life. That Grandma is an academic and author gives license for the writers for thought provoking, funny, smart dialog. That the grandchild is a wise B-student who crosses the street after a dog barks from behind a fence creates a vulnerability that made me care about her safety then and her well being as an adult in development. And in between the generations walked a layer at her treadmill desk, doing the things that gave financial life to her family, and complicated relationships with the one who came before and the one following... not so much in her footsteps. The clich� sandwiched generations, rye, chicken and sour dough. Girls, take your mom's to this movie. Mom's take your mom's to this movie. Mom's take your daughters and grand daughters to this show. I wish I could. I wish I knew what my mom really experienced instead of what I made up from what I saw and the snippets, the highlights of stories she revealed. I wish I had an opportunity to ask her to tell me the back stories of the turning points in her life. Reminding me of, The Turning Point, a wonderful Shirley McLain movie, and, of my own turning point, Lily Tomlin's, Search for Signs of Intelligent Life in the Universe... which my sister and I saw live on Christmas day the first year my son went off to his father's family to celebrate without me.

A touching, well-written comedy-drama about the choices we make, especially with regard to the people in our lives and the relationships we choose to have with them (and with ourselves). Despite a few somewhat unlikely plot elements, the film features a virtuoso, award-worthy performance by Lily Tomlin, along with a terrific supporting cast. Go see this one -- easily one of this year's best thus far.
Every relationship is interesting and moving. Lilly Tomlin and Sam Elliott prove that actors can get better with age!
Lily Tomlin shines like a fog light in the best, most well rounded, nuanced, superbly written, lesbian character in film history. CDW

This move shows the tender and vulnerable side of Lily Tomlin. Her acting is truly Oscar worthy. It's fresh and familiar all at the same time. Grandma, is funny in a 'witty' way; and it's a beautiful glimpse into the more serious side of Tomlin. This movie is delightful if you like being entertained and inspired at the same time, you are sure to love it. The supporting cast was also on point. Writing was really good, really noting negative about this work, simply stellar. You will laugh, cry and remember things you thought you wouldn't. It's an 11 out of 10 for me. Beautiful, beautiful, Lily Tomlin you have done it again. PS I love the dragonfly references in the movie.

A small story but a potent character study by one of cinema's greatest comic legends. Tomlin deserves an Oscar nomination for this nuanced portrayal of "a woman of a certain age" who never got the memo that grandmothers are supposed to stay home to knit and bake cookies.

Paul Weitz's film is brisk, funny, and insightful, and features a welcome return to cinema from the irresistible Lily Tomlin. It's just not quite as meaty as it could be, and at times plays it a bit too safe with its storyline.

Lily Tomlin has been a consistent comic joy in my life: she was on Laugh In when I was a teen. I looked forward to re-visiting her puckish humor in this film, but was disappointed to see that the screenwriter gave her an ornery and potty-mouthed character. I found Marcia Gay Harden funnier. Not Lily's fault: she is a wonder, left to her own devices. The movie did have its poignant moments. And I applaud the writer and director looking at the lives of women living on their own terms.

The trailer made me groan but then those glowing reviews! GRANDMA is like an annoying person you don't want to be around. But worst of all is just how utterly contrived and typical it is. OK, it's better than the really crappy trailer, and thank god it's only 75 minutes long. Even Tomlin is nothing special. In fact, she's actually better in the truly dreadful FRANKIE & GRACE. So she may be on a roll but a roll down Niagara Falls is still the end of your life. Yikes. You can skip GRANDMA. Really no reason to see it. Small thing, please let me age like Sam Elliott.
what a wholly unoriginal movie. Lily Tomlin as an angry lesbian who picks fights with everyone. Hated her, hated the movie

Lily Tomlin recently received and Emmy nomination for her co-starring role with Jane Fonda in the TV sitcom "Grace & Frankie." In "Grandma," playing the title role, Lily would be my current favorite for and Oscar nom. If not for the lanuage, this film would be good for the entire family. Lily told me not to call this a comeback, so I won't. I'll just say it's great to have Lily back.
Moving film, so well done. Acting, writing and directing are all pitch perfect. It's a lovely story with just enough quirkiness.
This film gives Lily Tomlin the perfect role and she plays it brilliantly. Paul Weitz's film is solid, but Lily Tomlin helps him take it to a whole other level.

Lilly Tomlin excels, stretching her performance in ways I haven't seen her do before. Funny, touching and poignant with edgy material. Many name actors in minor roles and cameos. A little uneven at times, but a real winner. Not for pro-life conservatives.
Lily tomlin is a huge plus in my book.

Brillante pel�cula cargada de s�tira, sarcasmo, humor negro y feminismo. todo encaja perfecta gracias al reparto espectacular y en especial por el gran papel de Lily Tomlin.
